node.title: Hopes US-China talks could help thaw frosty relations between Australia and China
node.alt: Trade Minister Dan Tehan speaks to the media
node.description: Australia is eager to "work through" its differences with China and resume trade relations after months of radio silence from its biggest economic partner.
node.content:
["Trade Minister Dan Tehan has suggested that this week's landmark meeting between Xi Jinping and Joe Biden might open the door for Australia to resume high-level contact with China's government.", "Australian government ministers have been effectively frozen out from meetings with their Chinese counterparts since the federal government called for an independent inquiry into the COVID-19 outbreak in April last year.", "Mr Tehan tried to break the impasse in January after taking over as Trade Minister, but his request has been ignored for 10\u00a0months.", "He told Bloomberg while visiting Singapore that Monday's meeting between the US President and his Chinese counterpart showed the value of dialogue.", "\"It was very good to see the two presidents be able to have a dialogue over the last 24 hours, and a very meaningful and significant dialogue,\" Mr Tehan said.", "", "
US\u00a0President Joe Biden speaks virtually with Chinese leader\u00a0Xi\u00a0Jinping from the White House earlier this week.(Reuters:\u00a0Jonathan Ernst)
", "\"And that's what Australia wants to be able to do with China itself. We are looking for constructive engagement.", "The relationship between Australia and China deteriorated sharply last year, with Beijing targeting multiple Australian goods with trade sanctions as disputes flared across multiple fronts.", "The federal government has repeatedly made it clear it wants to resume talks with Chinese ministers, but China has signalled that it wants Australia to make concrete concessions before that can happen.", "This morning Prime Minister Scott Morrison said Australia would \"welcome\" high-level dialogue with China at any time but again emphasised that the government would not compromise on any of Australia's core principles or policies.", "Mr Tehan also reiterated that China's government would have to end its freeze on ministerial talks if it wanted to begin formal talks with Australia over Beijing's bid to join a massive regional trade agreement, the\u00a0CPTPP.", "\"You have to be able to sit down and work through, especially, your market access issues when it comes to goods,\" he told Bloomberg.", "\"So, we would need some sort of ministerial dialogue to be able to work through that market accession.\"", "He also made it clear once again that Australia would only back China's bid if it wound back its punitive campaign of trade punishment.", "\"Obviously economic coercion, trade disputes, those types of things, would all have to be dealt with and we'd have to work through those, but also there would have to be that firm commitment to those gold standard rules,\" he said.", "", "
The Morrison government is keen to resume talks with China.(News Video)
", "
Meeting with US Commerce Secretary
", "The CPTPP was first championed by the Obama administration, but Donald Trump pulled the US out of the agreement.", "The Biden administration has signalled it will not re-join, because of fierce domestic political opposition.", "The US has instead promised to unveil a new Indo-Pacific economic framework which will lay out how it will revitalise its economic engagement in the region, but public details are still scant.", "Mr Tehan met with US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo in Singapore to discuss the framework and agreed to reconvene a bilateral critical mineral working group with US and Australian officials.", "The two also held a separate meeting with New Zealand Minister for Trade Damien O'Connor and Singapore Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong.", "After the meeting all four ministers said they has \"agreed to continue to strengthen efforts to help address shared priorities for countries in the Indo-Pacific region, including enhancing supply chain resilience, promoting infrastructure investment, growing the digital and green economies, towards broadly shared economic prosperity for the region.\"", "Some analysts have warned US strategy in the region was damaged by the Trump administration's isolationism and is still being undercut by anaemic economic engagement and diplomacy under Mr Biden.", "Australia has also signalled that it would like the US to revitalise its economic engagement in the broader region, particularly in South-East Asia."]
